title: 107_hr471
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Right-to-Know Act of 2001" requires disclosure of fire safety information for campus buildings. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a requirement for eligible institutions to disclose fire safety reports annually starting from the academic year 2001-2002. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment mandates eligible institutions to annually disclose fire safety reports starting from the academic year 2001-2002. These reports must include information on campus fire safety practices, student housing facilities equipped with fire safety systems, and statistics on fires and false alarms in the past two years. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment requires eligible institutions to disclose annual fire safety reports. These reports must include details on campus fire safety practices, student housing facilities, fire incidents, injuries, structural damage, fire and smoke alarms, fire escape planning, fire drills, and future fire safety improvements. The Secretary is not authorized to mandate specific fire safety policies, procedures, or practices for higher education institutions. Each institution participating in higher education programs must report fires and false alarms to the campus community and submit annual statistics to the Secretary for review and public access. The Secretary collaborates with higher education representatives to identify exemplary practices. The Secretary collaborates with higher education representatives to identify exemplary fire safety policies, procedures, and practices for reducing campus fires. The Secretary of Education collaborates with higher education representatives to identify exemplary fire safety policies, procedures, and practices for reducing campus fires. Additionally, the Secretary is required to report to Congress. Within one year of enacting this Act, the Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress analyzing fire safety systems in college facilities, determining appropriate standards, estimating costs to update nonconforming buildings, and providing recommendations for meeting fire safety standards on campuses. The Secretary of Education must report to Congress on fire safety systems in college facilities, cost estimates for updates, and funding recommendations.
